elements.title: Roxani Soutzos (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that, commenting on her support for the egalitarian Greek Republic as a Phanariote dame, Roxani Soutzos (pictured) said it was "[b]etter to be a servant in Greece liberated than a princess in Greece enslaved"?

elements.title: 900 West Randolph (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that 900 West Randolph, Chicago's first high-rise building built by a black-owned construction firm, has penthouses that can be rented for over $20,000 per month?

elements.title: Brian Kalbas (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Brian Kalbas helped recruit the player who would replace him in the number-one spot on his college tennis team?

elements.title: a Texas TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a company controlled by Lady Bird Johnson bought a Texas TV station from one of her college classmates?

elements.title: Michael McCown (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the "extreme lightness and luminous agility" of Michael McCown's voice in the roles of the Tempter and Nebuchadnezzar has been likened to that of Peter Pears?

elements.title: The Wizard of the Kremlin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that The Wizard of the Kremlin depicts a fictional éminence grise based on Vladislav Surkov, who was called one of Russia's "most intriguing figures" by The New York Times?

elements.title: Barcroft Boake (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Barcroft Boake, the author of one of Australia's most anthologised poems, hanged himself with a stockwhip a few months after it was published?

elements.title: Knock Knock Gang (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Knock Knock Gang's modus operandi involves deceiving drivers and passengers before robbing them?
